Let's say the string is stored in a variable s of length, say, 10 (since "BUG" is 3 characters, "OK" is 2). Then loop over each character:

score = 0

do i = 1, len_trim(s) c = s(i:i)
    if (mod(i-1,2) == 0) then  ! since in Fortran, indices start at 1, so i=1 corresponds to 0 in Java
        my_char = 'g'
    else
        my_char = 'p'
    end if
    if (c /= my_char) then
        if (my_char == 'p') then
            score = score +1
        else
            score = score -1
        end if
    end if
end do

    ! But let's code it properly
    character(len=20) :: score_str
    write(score_str, '(I0)') score
    character(len=20), dimension(10) :: tokens
    integer :: num_tokens, pos, i
    pos = 1
    num_tokens = 0
    do
        if (pos > len_trim(score_str)) exit
        call split_token(score_str, pos, tokens(num_tokens+1)) num_tokens = num_tokens + 1
    end do
    ! Now count until first zero
    third_output = 0
    do i = 1, num_tokens
        third_output = third_output + 1
        if (trim(tokens(i)) == "0") exit
    end do

    ! Output the third_output
    print *, third_output

contains
    subroutine split_token(str, pos, token)
        character(len=*), intent(in) :: str
        integer, intent(inout) :: pos
        character(len=*), intent(out) :: token
        integer :: start, end
        start = pos
        do while (start <= len_trim(str) .and. str(start:start) == ' ')
            start = start + 1
        end do
        if (start > len_trim(str)) then
            token = ''
            return
        end if
        end = start
        do while (end <= len_trim(str) .and. str(end:end) /= ' ')
            end = end + 1
        end do
        token = str(start:end-1)
        pos = end
    end subroutine split_token
end program main
